nameVariants.name: Alberni Girls Home
nameVariants.note: Also known as Indian Girls Home, Alberni. (Documents are unable to confirm the name of this school between 1897 and 1898).

nameVariants.name: Alberni Indian Residential School
nameVariants.note: In this time, the school was also known as Presbyterian Boarding School, Alberni Boarding School, Alberni Industrial Home, Indian Residential School, Alberni, Alberni Indian Residential School, Alberni Residential School, Alberni School, and Alberni Indian Boarding School.

nameVariants.name: Alberni Indian Student Residence
nameVariants.note: Also known as Alberni Student Residence.

desc: Alberni Girls Home was open at least as early as 1893 (some educational activities appear to have occurred in Alberni prior to 1893 but documents are unable to confirm this).
Alberni Boarding School destroyed by fire.
Opening of re-built Alberni Boarding School.
Alberni Residential School destroyed by fire.
One-room Alberni Indian Day School opened.
Coqualeetza IRS closed, transferring to Alberni IRS some staff, pupils and equipment.
Classroom building of the AIRS destroyed by fire.
Official opening of the re-built Alberni Indian Residential School.
Alberni school board agreed to provide room for senior high school students from AIRS.
Grades 7, 8 and 9 from AIRS admitted to A.W. Neill Junior High School.
Grades 4, 5 and 6 transferred to provincial schools.
Grades 1, 2 and 3 transferred to provincial schools.
Alberni Student Residence closed, building and land transferred to West Coast District Council of Indian Chiefs.

religiousGroups.group: Women's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada

writtenAgreements.desc: Agreement for the Operation of a School, between His Majesty the King, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada and the Reverend R.P. MacKay, D.D., Secretary of the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada. April 1, 1911.
Agreement for the Operation of Alberni Indian Residential School, between Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada and the United Church of Canada. June 22, 1962.

additionalInformation.notes: A series of correspondence in 1918 notes that a male student at the Alberni Indian Boarding School was subjected to a '... most brutal beating' at the hands of an employee of the school.
Another series of correspondence, this in 1922, indicates that an employee of the school whips, hits and chokes the boys
In 1995 Arthur Henry Plint pleaded guilty to 18 counts of indecent assault against a male, relating to 18 victims at Alberni IRS.
In 1997 Arthur Henry Plint pleaded guilty to 10 counts of indecent assault against a male, relating to 9 victims and 3 counts of assault causing bodily harm, relating to 3 victims, at Alberni IRS.
In October 2003, Donald Bruce Haddock pleaded guilty to four counts of indecent assault which occurred at Alberni IRS between 1948 and 1954.

additionalInformation.agressor: Michael Dennis Flynn and David Henry Forde
additionalInformation.notes: In November 2003, Michael Dennis Flynn and David Henry Forde were charged in connection with the allegations of sexual abuse at Alberni IRS.
Letters dated August 21, 1922, September 9, 1922 and November 6, 1922, indicate that several girls became pregnant by other students while attending the Alberni Industrial School.
An Inspector's Report dated October 19, 1941 notes '... a big boy hit a little boy several times and even kick [sic] him to get him to stand at attention.'
A letter dated June 11, 1965 notes that a male student has a 'Tendency to sexual delinquency plays with little girls, has exhibited himself on two occasions. Needs constant care and surveillance.'
A letter, dated January 12, 1968, indicates that a girl who was pregnant while attending AIRS was discharged from the school due to her pregnancy.
It appears there was an infirmary and dispensary in AIRS in at least the 1940s.
There were numerous outbreaks of influenza, pneumonia, mumps and measles at Albemi IRS.
The largest outbreak appears to have been an influenza epidemic which affected 184 pupils and half of the staff at AIRS in March 1951.
In 1966 and 1967 various surveys relating to hearing loss, dental conditions and general health were conducted at AIRS.
In 1922, there was discussion ofboys sneaking into the girls' dormitory at night and in 1923 various solutions were discussed to prevent this from occurring.

In 1927, the United Church decided that due to the '... trouble and friction ...' at the Alberni Indian Boarding School, the entire staff, including Principal Currie, were to be 'retired' effective June 30, 1927.
In 1928, the issue ofkeeping boys' and girls' separate during the night was raised in the context of constructing fire escapes.
It appears that high school students were permitted in the Alberni Student Residence, but as early as 1933 attended high school classes in provincial schools in Port Alberni.

Upon the destruction of the Alberni Residential School in 1937 by fire, the children in attendance were dispersed to various locations. Specifically, of the 112 children in attendance at the time of the fire 19 returned to the Cowichan Agency, 8 were placed in the Ahousaht School, 17 in the Ucluelet Day School, 37 were sent home 'at various points' and 31 remained in Alberni.

In 1941, there was correspondence on the installation of an extra fire door and potential disciplinary problems between boys and girls; the Principal assumed responsibility for proper discipline at the school.
In December 1948, pupils and staff of Alberni IRS composed a Newsletter entitled 'The Western Eagle'. This newsletter describes the life at the school.
In 1969 a child died at the AIRS, the cause of death was found to be accidental hanging.
An accident involving a van from the Alberni Student Residence in November 1972, resulted in the death of one boy from the residence while another boy lost his arm in the crash.
